Academic Integrity

International Center for Academic Integrity (ICAI) defines academic integrity as a commitment to six fundamental values: honesty, trust, fairness, respect, responsibility and courage. By embracing these fundamental values, instructors, students, staff, and administrators create effective academic communities where integrity is at the foundation. Without them, the work of teachers, learners, and researchers loses value and credibility. More than merely abstract principles, the fundamental values serve to inform and improve ethical decision-making capacities and behavior. They enable academic communities to translate ideals into action. [*1]

*1 Source: International Center for Academic Integrity (2014). The Fundamentals of Academic Integrity. Creative Commons: Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-NC-SA 4.0) https://academicintegrity.org/images/pdfs/20019_ICAI-Fundamental-Values_R12.pdf

Course Design




Course design emphasizes alignment by connecting learning outcomes with course content and aligned activities and assessments (Biggs & Tang, 2011). A well-designed course scaffolds student learning levels and encourages reflection to deepen knowledge building (Biggs & Tang, 2011). This student-centered approach fosters autonomy, competence, and a sense of relatedness among students through assessments and activities (Niemiec & Ryan, 2009). Student-centered practices in course design promote authentic learning experiences that support well-being and foundational knowledge (Fink, 2013).

Educational Media

Educational Media is defined as “channels of communication that carry messages with an instructional purpose. (Webcrawler, 2013).  We will concentrate on electronic media, and provide resources and tips on audio, visual and audio-visual media, and multimedia in learning environments. Not all media is the right choice for every teaching moment. Selecting the right kind of media for your teaching purpose is just as important as the content itself. The SECTIONS model (Bates, 2015) assists educators in choosing the right media for their teaching and learning environment.

Privacy

With the inception of the internet and its ability to share and collect private data, the creation of privacy laws to protect the individual became necessary. Freedom of Information Protection of Privacy Act (FIPPA) guides digital users on how to protect private information and holds accountable organizations and individuals to laws that are enforced to protect digital users. In this section, you will find information about FIPPA and what it means to you as an instructor as well as an internet user. Selkirk College's "approach to privacy is to ensure the responsible use of information and safeguarding human dignity while optimizing the beneficial use of data for decision-making" (Selkirk College, 2022).

Applied Learning

Applied learning refers to the design of significant learning experiences linked directly with course and program content that intentionally develop students’ academic, personal & professional skills. The hallmarks of applied learning are systems & structures that are flexible and responsive to the unique teaching skills, learning spaces, communication and assessment strategies required to provide authentic, thought-provoking learning experiences that meaningfully contend with current issues facing society, government, business and industry (Camosun College Applied Learning Framework, p.3)

Mental Health in Education

Mental health support in post-secondary education plays a crucial role in helping students navigate the challenges of academic life. It involves providing resources and services like counselling and stress management strategies to address issues such as anxiety, depression, and burnout. Instructors can play a key role in supporting learners' mental health by providing information and referrals to services in course materials and during class time. There are a number of resources available for instructors including workshops and trainings that increase mental health literacy and skills for engaging with students and community members.

 Effective mental health support promotes students' well-being, enhances their academic performance, and contributes to overall personal growth. It also helps create a supportive campus environment where students and staff feel valued and understood, leading to improved retention and success rates.

Universal Design for Learning (UDL)

Universal Design for Learning (UDL), is an educational framework promoting accessible learning environments for all students by dismantling physical and cognitive barriers. “Unlike the principle of accommodation, which reactively seeks to provide access to an individual, universal design emphasizes proactive approaches that enhance learning for a wide range of participants. While some accommodations may need to be made on a case-by-case basis, approaching teaching with universal design in mind makes it easier for people with and without disabilities and impairments to participate. The default focus therefore shifts from the individual or the disability to the promotion of inclusion as a general goal” (UT, 2022). 

University of Toronto (2022). Fostering Accessible Learning. Retrieved from https://tatp.utoronto.ca/teaching-toolkit/effective-strategies/accessible-learning/#FAL6

Ethic of Care

A Sense of Community in a course will benefit from an Ethic of Care. Feminist ethics of care is an act of critical thinking "based on the claim that care and support are just as important functions and outcomes in the university as are efficiency and more measurable outcomes. It is argued that by building strong relations and engaging with each other as full human beings, we can create better and more meaningful processes, results, and impacts (Bergland, 2018). " (Verdera 2019, p 98). If you are new to Ethics of Care a good starting point to learn about the field of study would be Verdara's 2019 article on Care Ethics in Universities: Beyond an Easy “Add and Stir” Solution. A particular section to read would be: Caring as an Alternative Path, Not Something to Be Added. Nel Noddings is one of the leading voices in this field.

1. Sustainability

Selkirk College Sustainability Plan

Selkirk College will take a future-focused, action-oriented and collaborative approach to the interconnected sustainability challenges of our time. The college is committed to integrating sustainability into student learning, services, operations, work force development, and campus culture. Our approach to climate action will include measures to adapt to projected climate impacts and strategies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions (mitigation) as we recognize the need to build resilience. Selkirk College will support students and employees to become informed citizens, equipped with the knowledge, skills, values and attitudes to bring about necessary global transformations.
